//notes: config tool on the American site has a whole lot more visual options
though configurable in length and diameter upon manufacture, we assume set dimensions and calculate the entire cover as a cylinder
these dimensions appear to be within reason for the product: 7 in. is a common suppressor length, and an average diameter between 1 in. and 2 in. would be 1.5 in.
description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  "HTP" stands for "High Temperature Python", referencing a previous model by the same company.  The inner core is rated for 3000°F, or around 1650°C.  Three Velcro straps supposed with plastic buckles allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- "Cole-TAC", with the initial C looking like a scope reticle -- is sewn onto a leaf, just before the farthest strap.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.

notes: trim applies to the internal part of the cover, where a suppressor would be, a space that would otherwise be empty and folded through

//material: while kevlar isn't clearly stated in the source, this appears to be the material of the bottom layer touching the suppressor in other models

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a clean and unassuming design.  The cover is rated for 3150°F, or around 1730°C, making it the highest-rated cover on the market.  An elaborate system of cords allows for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- "Cole-TAC", with the initial C looking like a scope reticle -- is sewn onto a leaf, on the side closer to the muzzle.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.
//weight: listed as 0.25 oz / in., or 0.28 g / mm
//material: source also lists carbon fiber, but as of 0.G it isn't in the game

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a clean and unassuming design.  The entire cover is rated for 1800°F, or around 980°C.  Three Velcro straps over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- a Spartan-looking helmet, with the eyeholes in the shape of two suppressed pistols -- is sewn next to the farthest strap.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.
//weight: however, we can infer that it's heavier than the default weight because it shares a similar construction to the Cole-TAC HTP cover
we err on the side of caution and use a similar, though slightly-smaller, weight for SC-7

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a clean and unassuming design.  The entire cover is rated for 800°F, or around 430°C.  Cords over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.
//weight: source lists as 0.81 lbs, which seems too high
right now, this cover is the worst possible choice for a gun, with its low bonuses and high weight
for the purposes of balance, we assume that 0.81 lbs is the weight of the largest possible length: 10.375 in.
from that, we extrapolate the weight of this 7-in. cover: 0.81 lbs ≈ 230 g / 10.375 ≈ 22.17 * 7 ≈ 155 g

notes: trim applies to the internal part of the cover, where a suppressor would be, a space that would otherwise be empty and folded through

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a rugged-looking, almost jury-rigged design, with Liberty's Defense logo -- a simplified figure of an archer with a large bow -- near the front of the cover.  Its mineral-based inner core is rated for 3000°F, or around 1650°C, while the Kevlar outer sleeve is rated for 2000°F, or around 1100°C.  Stainless steel cord over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.
//weight: PDF source provides a listing of weights for specific models of suppressors, because a cover is generally bespoke
to make it more generic, we can calculate an approximate weight for a 7-in. suppressor of similar construction
taking Dead Air Nomad 30 suppressor as the starting point: 7.7 oz / 6.5 in ≈ 1.19 * 7 in. ≈ 8.3 oz ≈ 235 g
//material: inner core is a combination of Kevlar, basalt, amorphous silica, and aluminized silica

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover, from Burn Proof Gear.  Its fiberglass inner core is rated for 2000°F, or around 1100°C, while the Nomex outer sleeve is rated for 1000°F, or around 540°C.  Cords over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.

notes: trim applies to the internal part of the cover, where a suppressor would be, a space that would otherwise be empty and folded through

//heat_tolerance: assumes one of the higher-temp models

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  HAD stands for "Heat Abatement Device".  Its inner core is rated for 3000°F, or around 1650°C, while the outer sleeve is rated for 2000°F, or around 1100°C.  Cords over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.

notes: trim applies to the internal part of the cover, where a suppressor would be, a space that would otherwise be empty and folded through

description: A rubber suppressor cover.  Its unique design and material offer V2 an interesting feel, without sacrificing performance.  On top of deep grooves molded into the cover, a flat logo of Manta Defense is printed.  Like other suppressor covers, it requires a suppressor of at least 7 in. in length.

notes: trim applies to the internal part of the cover, where a suppressor would be, a space that would otherwise be empty
while this model doesn't appear to fold or compress, we can assume that the extra space could be filled with smaller items
